Solve the following system of linear equations:

x + 4y = 10

3x - y = 5
message_2:
To solve this system of linear equations, we can use the substitution or elimination method. In this case, we will use the elimination method.

First, we will multiply the first equation by 3 and the second equation by 1 to make the coefficients of x in both equations equal:

(1) 3(x + 4y) = 3(10)
(2) 1(3x - y) = 1(5)

Now we have:

(1) 3x + 12y = 30
(2) 3x - y = 5

Next, we will subtract equation (2) from equation (1):

(1) - (2): (3x + 12y) - (3x - y) = 30 - 5

This simplifies to:

13y = 25

Now, we will solve for y:

y = 25/13

Now that we have the value of y, we can substitute it back into either equation (1) or (2) to solve for x. We will use equation (1):

x + 4(25/13) = 10

x + 100/13 = 10

Now, we will subtract 100/13 from both sides of the equation:

x = 10 - 100/13

To subtract the fractions, we need a common denominator, which is 13:

x = (130 - 100)/13

x = 30/13

So, the solution to the system of linear equations is:

x = 30/13 and y = 25/13
